issues.text: Whether the respondent has ratified the impugned transaction, received benefit under it with full knowledge, and is precluded by ratification, election or estoppel from challenging its validity

anchor.surface_text: The principal point which has been urged before us by Mr R. Keshav Aiyangar on behalf of the appellant is that in substance the respondent has ratified the impugned transaction, has received benefit under it, and by his conduct has affirmed it, and so it is not open to him to challenge its validity and binding character.

holdings.text: The plea of surrender raised by the appellant could not be sustained.

anchor.surface_text: Incidentally a plea of surrender was also raised by the appellant. Mr. Justice Kunhiraman [...] Before the appeal court it was conceded that the plea of surrender raised by the appellant could not be sustained, and that the contention that the respondent was bound by the family arrangement could not also be sustained.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Conceded by appellant before High Court and not disputed before Supreme Court.

holdings.text: The transaction which took place on May 27, 1893, as a result of the dispute between the two widows and with the intervention of the well-wishers of the family is not a family arrangement as understood under Hindu Law.

anchor.surface_text: There can be numberdoubt that the transaction which took place on May 27, 1893, as a result of the dispute between the two widows and with the intervention of the well-wishers of the family is number a family arrangement as understood under Hindu Law. This position was conceded before the High Court and is number disputed before us Ex. D-2 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Transaction merely settled disputes between two widows, not involving reversioners; position conceded by parties.

holdings.text: The appellant had failed to establish his plea of ratification against the respondent; respondent not precluded by ratification, election, or estoppel from challenging the transaction.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, in our opinion, the High Court was right in holding that the appellant had failed to establish his plea of ,ratification against the respondent. Indeed, to hold otherwise would be in the words of the Privy Council a quite unwarrantable proposition.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Respondent was minor, not party to transaction; receipt of benefit routine and without full knowledge of rights as reversioner; distinguished precedents like Sahu Madho Das, Dhiyan Singh; patta routine, prior admissions limited to widow's lifetime.

holdings.text: The impugned transfer is not justified by legal necessity.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, in our opinion, the companyclusion is inescapable that the impugned transfer is number justified by legal necessity.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Out of Rs.10,000 consideration, only Rs.776 represents debts; rest (document expenses Rs.558, funeral Rs.409) not legal necessity; document gives effect to invalid prior arrangement to avoid sanction under letters of administration.

holdings.text: An alienation by a widow is not void but only voidable by reversioners, who may be precluded by ratification, election, or estoppel.

anchor.surface_text: In that case this Court has held that it is settled law that an alienation by a widow in exercise of her powers is number altogether void but only voidable by the reversioners who may either singly or as a body be precluded

holdings.reasoning_summary: Principle restated from precedents like Sahu Madho Das; applied but not novel.

holdings.text: Mere receipt of benefit under a widow's alienation does not preclude a presumptive reversioner from challenging it upon reversion falling open.

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, the sale deed which was executed by defendant 3 in favour of the two widows is of numberassistance because it was obviously a sale by defendant 3 of his reversionary rights which were then numberbetter than spes suwessionis

holdings.reasoning_summary: Must show conduct amounting to ratification with full knowledge; mere benefit insufficient, per Rangaswami Gounden.

precedents.citation: Sahu Madho Das v. Pandit Mukand Ram  1

anchor.surface_text: Sahu Madho Das v. Pandit Mukand Ram  1 . In that case this Court has held that it is settled law that an alienation by a widow in exercise of her powers is number altogether void but only voidable by the reversioners who may either singly or as a body be precluded from exercising their right to avoid it either by express ratification or by acts which treat it as valid or binding.

precedents.case_name: Sahu Madho Das v Pandit Mukand Ram
precedents.cited_proposition: an alienation by a widow in exercise of her powers is not altogether void but only voidable by the reversioners who may either singly or as a body be precluded from exercising their right to avoid it either by express ratification or by acts which treat it as valid or binding
precedents.cited_holding: it is settled law that an alienation by a widow in exercise of her powers is number altogether void but only voidable by the reversioners who may either singly or as a body be precluded from exercising their right to avoid it either by express ratification or by acts which treat it as valid or binding. This Court also observed that it is a principle of general application underlying many branches of the law that a person who with full knowledge of his rights has once elected to assent to a transaction voidable at his instance and has thus elected number to exercise his right to avoid it, cannot go back on that election and avoid it at a later stage having made his election he is bound by it.

anchor.surface_text: Dhiyan Singh v. Jugal Kishore  2 . In that case it was held that even if the impugned award was invalid the plaintiff who disputed its validity was barred from making that claim by reason of estoppel.

precedents.cited_proposition: even if the impugned award was invalid the plaintiff who disputed its validity was barred from making that claim by reason of estoppel

anchor.surface_text: Kanhai Lal v. Brij Lal  1 . When we turn to the Privy Council decision itself we find that Kanhai Lal, who was held by the Privy Council to be precluded from challenging the arrangement to which he was a party, had set up a title in himself on the strength of an alleged adoption,

precedents.cited_proposition: if a person having full knowledge of his rights as a possible reversioner enters into a transaction which settles his claim as well as the claim of his opponents at the relevant time, he cannot be permitted to go back on that arrangement when reversion actually falls open

anchor.surface_text: Rangaswami Gounden v. Nachiappa Gounden  2  the Privy Council had to deal mainly with the question of surrender, its theory and its essential features. Incidentally it had also to deal with the case of reversioner who had taken from an alienee from a Hindu widow a mortgage of a property which included a part of the property alienated,

precedents.cited_proposition: the mere fact that the reversioner has received some benefit under the transaction or has not challenged the validity of the transaction when it took place cannot bar his rights as a reversioner when reversion in his favour falls open
precedents.cited_holding: to hold that by doing so , observed the Privy Council, he barred himself from asserting his own title to a part of what was mortgaged seems to their Lordships a quite unwarrantable proposition

anchor.surface_text: Ramgouda Annagouda v. Bhausaheb  1 . In this case the widow of the last male holder had alienated nearly the whole of the property of her husband by three deeds executed and registered on the same day. One of the deeds was in favour of a presumptive reversioner.

precedents.cited_proposition: if a presumptive reversioner is a party to an arrangement which may properly be called a family arrangement and takes benefit under it, he would be precluded from disputing the validity of the said arrangement when reversion falls open and he becomes the actual reversioner
precedents.cited_holding: the three deeds had to be regarded as forming one transaction entered into by all the persons interested in the properties, and that after the reversion fell open, the reversioners who were parties to the said transactions were precluded from disputing the two alienations by reason of their conduct

anchor.surface_text: That leaves the question of legal necessity to be considered. The High Court has held that the impugned transfer cannot be said to have been justified by legal necessity and, in our opinion, the finding of the High Court on this point is obviously right. In dealing with this question it may be relevant to recall that the widow

outcome.relief_summary: Impugned transfer by widows held not binding on reversioner as neither family arrangement, nor ratified, nor supported by legal necessity; respondent entitled to possession of item No. 1 in Schedule II
directions: Suit to proceed before Official Referee for mesne profits (as per High Court decree upheld)

Mr. Justice Kunhiraman [...] Before the appeal court it was conceded that the plea of surrender raised by the appellant could not be sustained, and that the contention that the respondent was bound by the family arrangement could not also be sustained.

That leaves the question of legal necessity to be considered. The High Court has held that the impugned transfer cannot be said to have been justified by legal necessity and, in our opinion, the finding of the High Court on this point is obviously right. anchor.surface_text: There can be numberdoubt that the transaction which took place on May 27, 1893, as a result of the dispute between the two widows and with the intervention of the well-wishers of the family is number a family arrangement as understood under Hindu Law. This position was conceded before the High Court and is number disputed before us Ex. D-2 .

That leaves the question of legal necessity to be considered. The High Court has held that the impugned transfer cannot be said to have been justified by legal necessity and, in our opinion, the finding of the High Court on this point is obviously right.
